PatientMatching.TEXT:
Record date: 2083-07-18
July 18, 2083
Vincent Ventura, M.D. 4971 Edmatteric Drive Cheney, TX 37523
RE: Peggy Tinsley MR #236-67-03-3
Dear Dr. Ventura:
Peggy Tinsley was seen in the renal clinic today. This patient with end stage renal disease secondary to diabetes was initiated on hemodialysis 2 weeks ago in MH. She has been doing well except for the complaint of fevers and rigors intermittently for the past week. There is no history of cough, dyspnea, or chest pain. She denies any dysuria, urgency, or frequency. Her blood sugars at home have been between 120 and 180.
Her current medications include Tums 5 to 6 tabs with meals, Erythropoietin, Premarin and Provera, Nephrox 150 mg tid, insulin NPH 10 units qam.
On July 17, after hemodialysis, Ms. Tinsley was given a partial dose of Vancomycin and developed pruritus. CBC at the time revealed a white count of 6.2 with a hematocrit of 25.2. Blood cultures were sent.
On examination today this lady appeared well with a BP of 110/60 and a pulse of 88. She was afebrile. Head and neck examination was unremarkable and chest was clear to IPPA. On cardiovascular examination JVP was at the sternal angle and there was no peripheral edema. Heart sounds were normal.
Urinalysis did not reveal and white cells and contained 3+ protein and 2+ glucose.
Miss Tinsley should be followed up at her dialysis center. There does not appear to be any evidence of a graft infection. She should also have a urine sent for culture to rule out urinary tract infection. Because of her early satiety she has been eating poorly and we might suggest that she be started on a gastroprokinetic agent such as Cisapride 10 mg qid. Vincent Ventura, M.D. -2- RE: Peggy Tinsley MR #236-67-03-3
Thank you for allowing us to be involved in the care of this patient.
Yours sincerely,
Martin Y. Pruitt, M.D. Renal Fellow
Y. Quinton Xanders, M.D. Attending Physician
DD: 07/18/83 DT: 07/23/83 DV: 07/18/83
/bradford

**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2083-11-01
June 6, 2083
Vincent Ventura, M.D. 0758 Edmatteric Drive Cheney, TX 37523
Re: Peggy Tinsley MR# 236-67-03-3
Dear Dr. Ventura:
Peggy Tinsley was seen in the Renal Clinic today. Her chief symptomatic complaint is severe pruritus, which has not improved much with Benadryl. She has yet to fill the prescription for Sarna lotion. Her diarrhea has improved with Imodium, and she brought in samples for cultures today. Her appetite has improved somewhat. She notes exertional fatigue and shortness of breath. Medications include Phoslo 1 tablet t.i.d., Lasix 160 mg b.i.d., Altase 2.5 mg b.i.d., Lopressor 100 mg b.i.d., NPH 10 units q.d., iron t.i.d.
On examination, weight was 46.8 kilos, which is stable. Heart rate was 72, blood pressure 130/64. JVP was clearly seen at 6 cm greater than the sternal angle, and there was 1 plus peripheral edema. There was no S3. Chest examination revealed bibasilar inspiratory crackles. Her left hand is no longer cold, but the PTFE graft remains slightly edematous.
Blood work from May 30th showed a hematocrit of 23, potassium 5.2, bicarbonate 15, BUN 91, creatinine 7.9, calcium 5.5., phosphate 5.2, albumin 3.4.
We will continue to hold off on dialysis until such time as Peggy's PTFE graft is suitable. This will save her the additional morbidity of a semipermanent IJ catheter. She is more hypervolemic than last week, and I added Zaroxolyn 2.5 mg in the morning to her diuretic regimen. By oversight, she was not started on Rocaltrol, and I have started her on Rocaltrol .25 mcg p.o. q.d., and Nephrocaps 1 p.o. q.d.
Page 2 Vincent Ventura, M.D. Re: Peggy Tinsley MR# 236-67-03-3 June 6, 2083
A follow-up appointment was arranged in one week's time.
Yours sincerely,
Keith Quant, M.D. Renal Fellow
Y. Quinton Xanders, M.D.
DD: 6-6-83 DT: 06/13/83 DV: 6-6-83

**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2085-09-02
September 03, 2085
Bill X. Stafford, M.D. Chief, Transplant Divistion Department of Surgery Family Practice Missoula
Re: Peggy Tinsley FPM#: 236-67-03-3
Dear Dr. Stafford:
I was asked to provide a cardiologic evaluation on Mrs. Tinsley with a concentration on her appropriateness to be listed as a recipient for a cadaver renal transplant. In summary, she is a 46 year old woman who has been an insulin dependent diabetic since the age of 29 and has been on hemodialysis since 2083. By report, her other complications for diabetes include retinopathy, peripheral neuropathy, and peripheral vascular disease. In viewing her present history, she works in the Houghton Mifflin Harcourt learning technology department. Her three times a week hemodialyses are uncomplicated. She does, however, experience occasional chest pressure with activities and on rare occasions has had nocturnal angina. These episodes are relieved by nitroglycerin. Mrs. Tinsley has also noted that with walking she will occasionally get short of breath which is relieved by slowing down.
In addition to diabetes and hypertension which was present only pre-dialysis, she has been and continues to be a smoker. Her cholesterol by one report was 228 mg/dl. I don't have fractionations and her family history is unknown.
A report of an echocardiogram from April of 2083, shows mild ventricular hypertrophy in the presence of mitral insufficiency, preserved LV size and function. She had an exercise tolerance test in February of 2085. On a modified protocol, she went for less than 4 1/2 minutes. This is equivalent to not even completing stage 1 of the standard Bruce. With that, she did develop chest pain and had 2 mm of ST depression. That study was accompanied by both fixed and reversible isotopic perfusion changes in the septum consistent with prior non-transmural infarct with exercise induced ischemia. As was apparent to those involved, even the non-isotope portion alone was worrisome for high grade coronary disease and led to the recommendation for a cardiac catheterization.
That study was done in Macdonald Hospital and at this time, I only have the report. However, from this report, there was preserved LV function with anterior lateral hypokinesis and trace MR that is consistent with the echo and the thallium studies. Coronary angiography showed by report, diffuse involvement of proximal mid-LAD without specific focal stenosis until an 80% mid- LAD. The circumflex was also diffusely diseased and there was a discrete stenosis in the mid section of a large marginal. The right coronary artery was diffusely diseased with a discrete stenosis. At that time, the recommendation was to continue medical therapy.
Her medical therapy at this time is estrogen replacement with prempro 2.5 mg once a day, tenormin 25 mg qd, aspirin one every other day in addition to her supplemental vitamins, iron and twice daily insulin therapy.
In rounding out her medical history, her surgical procedures have involved the hemodialysis access. She has had one pregnancy 28 years ago without complications. I also elicited a history of some focal arm weakness and occasional slurring of speech. This was difficult to pin down, but is of some concern.
On exam, her blood pressure was 150/80 mm Hg, pulse 90 regular, her weight 95 lbs. Her hemodialysis shunt is on the left arm. There was a right carotid bruit, neck veins were not distended. Lungs were clear, PMI was displaced and sustained. There was an S4, no S3 and there was a holo systolic murmur at the apex. Abdomen was benign, femoral pulses were intact, extremities were without edema. The electrocardiogram showed sinus rhythm, diffuse STT changes. There were no pathologic Q waves.
Although the focus of this evaluation was originally for transplant candidacy, I am concerned about her current cardiac status. She is a young diabetic woman, symptomatic of both shortness of breath and chest pain and on exercise test, has limited functional capacity. The coronary angiography reveals a presence of multi-vessel disease. Even without seeing the primary data which I hope to do in the next week, it would be unlikely that she would be an angioplasty candidate, given the poor results in diabetics. Therefore, coronary revascularization for her would be coronary artery bypass surgery.
Obviously, I would like to review the films first, and speak with Dr. Upson regarding augmentation of her anti-anginals. I would also like to add pravastatin at this time, starting with only 10 mg and obtain non-invasive studies of the carotids. As indicated, although the focus of this evaluation was her suitability for transplantation, the issue of controlling symptomatic coronary artery disease in this young woman became more pressing.
I look forward to working with you and the other physicians in her care.
Sincerely,
Quentin U. Johnson, M.D., Ph.D.
Quentin U. Johnson, M.D., Ph.D.

FPM EMERGENCY DEPT VISIT
TINSLEY,PEGGY R 236-67-03-3 VISIT DATE: 02/06/87 PRESENTING COMPLAINT: The patient is a 48-year-old female who has had a kidney transplant as well as an extensive cardiac history who comes in complaining of fatigue and shortness of breath. HISTORY OF PRESENTING COMPLAINT: She was seen primarily by Dr. Robert Villasenor. She also complains of pleuritic chest pain and a cough. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Are as documented in the written chart by Dr. Villasenor. MEDICATIONS: Are as documented in the written chart by Dr. Villasenor. ALLERGIES: Are as documented in the written chart by Dr. Villasenor. SOCIAL HISTORY AND FAMILY HISTORY: Are as documented in the written chart by Dr. Villasenor. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Her temperature is 99. Her other vital signs are stable. Her O2 sat is 96% on room air. Her exam is as noted in the written chart. Of note, on her cardiovascular exam: She has a regular rate and rhythm with a 2/6 systolic murmur. The lungs show left lower lobe crackles. LABORATORY EVALUATION: Are notable for a white blood cell count of 12.5 and a hematocrit of 45.3. Chest x-ray shows an infiltrate in the superior segment of the left upper lobe. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: This is a 48-year-old female status post a kidney transplant who now has a left upper lobe pneumonia. DISPOSITION (including condition upon discharge): The plan is to admit the patient for IV antibiotics. Condition on admission is satisfactory. ___________________________________ JD545/5915 SARINA BOOTH, M.D. SB17 D:02/06/87 T:02/07/87 Dictated by: SARINA BOOTH, M.D. SB17

FPM EMERGENCY DEPT VISIT
TINSLEY,PEGGY R 236-67-03-3 VISIT DATE: 03/01/88 The patient was seen in the emergency department with Dr. Singleton, history per Dr. Singleton. PRESENTING COMPLAINT: Ear pain and rash. HISTORY OF PRESENTING COMPLAINT: The patient is a 49 year old female with past medical history positive for recent transplant, hypertension, Insulin dependent diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery bypass grafting who presented to the emergency department with right ear pain for the last week now. She now has a petechia rash in the periumbilical area. She has no fevers, chills, cough, trauma, or other complaints. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: As documented by Dr. Singleton. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: As documented by Dr. Singleton. MEDICATIONS: As documented by Dr. Singleton. ALLERGIES: As documented by Dr. Singleton. SOCIAL HISTORY AND FAMILY HISTORY: As documented by Dr. Singleton. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: The patient is in no acute distress. Her blood pressure is 220/80, pulse 80 and regular, respirations 16, the patient is afebrile with oxygen saturation 97% on room air. Examination of her right air shows positive cerumen impaction and question of otitis externa. Otherwise her airway is patent. Her neck is supple without jugular venous distension, nodes, or bruits. Her lungs are clear. Her heart reveals a regular rate and rhythm without murmur. Her abdomen is soft, positive petechial rash on the left aspect of the umbilicus, not raised, no hives or tenderness over the graft. No rebound, guarding, or rigidity. Her extremities have no deformities. Neurologic examination is non focal. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. LABORATORY EVALUATION: Complete blood count shows a white blood cell count of 5.8, hematocrit 35.8. Electrolytes are within normal limits. BUN is 16.9 with creatinine 2.8. THERAPY RENDERED/COURSE IN ED: The patient was seen in the emergency department by ENT and by the transplant service. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: Cerumen impaction and otitis externa to the ear. Elevated BUN and creatinine. DISPOSITION (including condition upon discharge): The patient was admitted for further evaluation and treatment. She was admitted in stable condition. ___________________________________ MA317/6938 D:03/01/88 T:03/02/88 Dictated by: UNKNOWN Y. PARRA, M.D. UP65 ******** Not reviewed by Attending Physician ********
